awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Numerical Methods and Computational Infrastructure for Simulating Prosthetic Heart Valve Function and Dysfunction
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance mathematical methods and computational software for simulating the dynamics of prosthetic heart valves.  In the United States, heart valve diseases affect approximately 8.5% of the population aged 65 to 74 years, and approximately 13.3% of those aged 75 years or older.  Treatment for severe aortic valve disease is generally to replace the heart valve with a mechanical or bioprosthetic valve, and approximately 70,000 aortic valve replacements are performed in the U.S. each year.  Bioprosthetic heart valves (BHVs) degrade over time, however, and these devices have a typical durable lifetime of only 10-15 years.  To date, there have been relatively few studies on modeling BHV fatigue, and there are no predictive models of BHV failure.  The methods created in this project can yield advanced fluid-structure interaction (FSI) models of heart valve function as well as the first FSI modeling tools for simulating BHV valve failure.  By advancing broadly applicable FSI modeling technologies and their specific application to heart valve dynamics, the project aligns with NFS's mission of promoting the progress of science and advancing national health.

This project will integrate higher-order immersed boundary (IB) methods, peridynamics, and turbulence modeling to predict prosthetic heart valve function and dysfunction (fatigue and failure).  The project will advance cardiovascular FSI simulation accuracy by developing and analyzing two classes of sharp-interface immersed boundary (IB) methods capable of using experimentally constrained elasticity models with complex, three-dimensional geometries and integrating large-eddy simulation (LES) turbulence models with these new FSI methods.  This project also aims to develop new FSI methods for simulating tissue failure by integrating IB methods with peridynamics, which is a nonlocal formulation of solid mechanics that is well suited for modeling structural failure.  These models will be validated using experimental data obtained in ongoing studies at the FDA Heart Valve Lab.  These methods will be implemented within the open-source IBAMR software, which is used by many independent research groups in a broad range of fields.  This project also integrates research aims with an educational plan leverages UNC's outstanding high-performance computing environment, experimental facilities available to UNC's applied math group, and UNC's major new makerspace initiative, BeAM (Be a Maker).  Finally, research and educational products of this project will be incorporated into ongoing activities at UNC's main science outreach unit, the Morehead Planetarium & Science Center.

por.por_cntn:
Accomplishments and Impact

Advances in Computational Methods

This project made significant contributions to computational science and engineering, particularly to computer methods for modeling fluid-structure interaction. It focused on the development of sharp-interface immersed boundary methods and immersed peridynamics methods. These advancements allow for more precise simulations of systems that fundamentally involve interactions between fluid flows and flexible structures such as heart valves. Methods developed in this project improve our ability to perform computer simulations of such systems by improving the accuracy of the computer models and by enabling models that capture material damage and failure.

Software Development

A key outcome of our research has been the substantial enhancement of the IBAMR software, which is community software for the immersed boundary (IB) method that supports adaptive mesh refinement (AMR). By integrating novel computational methods into IBAMR, this project has broadened this software's applicability and utility in tackling challenging problems in fluid-structure interaction. This effort not only fosters innovation within the field but also supports a wide range of research in diverse fields of science and engineering, making cutting-edge computational tools widely accessible.

Application Impacts

This work has direct applications in computational biomedical engineering, particularly in simulating the dynamics of heart valves. These simulations improve understanding of how prosthetic valves interact with blood flow, potentially informing the design of more durable and effective devices. While direct improvements to heart valve design and patient care are longer-term goals, our project lays the foundational computational groundwork to support these advances.

Interdisciplinary Collaboration

This project also supported progress towards validating models of bioprosthetic heart valves through collaborations with regulatory scientists at the Food and Drug Administration. Project outcomes include some of the first direct comparisons between immersed boundary models of bioprosthetic heart valves and experimental data, including data provided by the FDA’s Heart Valve Lab.

Educational Outreach and Public Engagement

A significant aspect of the project included engaging with the broader community through educational outreach, particularly through our collaboration with the Morehead Planetarium and Science Center. The "Valves Inside" activity, developed for young students, serves as a bridge between complex engineering concepts and public understanding.

Professional Development

The project provided extensive professional development opportunities for graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. Participants gained experience in advanced computational methods, interdisciplinary research, and collaboration with regulatory bodies and industry partners. Training included technical skills in computational modeling and software development, as well as soft skills in communication, teamwork, and problem-solving. Many participants have moved on to positions in academia, industry, and regulatory agencies, demonstrating the project's role in fostering the next generation of scientists and engineers.

Conclusion

The project has advanced computational methods for fluid-structure interaction that can be applied to enable applications in biomedical engineering, enhancing the capabilities of the IBAMR software, and contributing to the understanding of heart valve dynamics. These efforts have laid a solid foundation for future research in medical device design and patient care. Moreover, the project's success in professional development and public engagement highlights the broader value of computational science as a tool for education, innovation, and societal benefit.

 


Last Modified: 03/23/2024
Modified by: Boyce E Griffith
